Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Mobile and E-network Smart Health (MESH)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Heart disease is responsible for 24.2% of the deaths in Unites States in 2010, and annual economic costs related to heart diseases are around $448.5 billion in the Unites States. Smart cardiac care calls for on-line monitoring, early identification of disease patterns and timely delivery of life-saving preventive care. Real-time electrocardiogram (ECG) contains a wealth of information on cardiac dynamics. Realizing the promise of ECG sensing, however, depends to a great extent on the advancement in information processing methodologies. Existing methodologies increasingly fail to address fundamental issues important to patient-centered care. The proposed technology, Mobile and E-network Smart Health (MESH), advances cardiac telemedicine with wireless sensors, smart mobile devices, and big data analytics. Specifically, the proposed technology enables mobile-based ECG sensing and network-based information processing for anyone, anytime and anywhere (especially in rural areas and developing countries).

The MESH technology supplies in-situ information processing capabilities, and enables physicians to access the patients' ECG signals in real time, remotely interact with patients and rapidly respond to life-threatening cardiac disorders. The MESH technology will overcome critical technological barriers in the early identification of acute cardiac events, personalized cardiac monitoring, and smarter management of heart health. The MESH technology will bring the ECG to people's daily life and raise the public awareness of smarter health and wellbeing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Internet of Things (IoT) provides an unprecedented opportunity to realize smart automated systems such as a smart healthcare system. Wearable biosensing and mobile technology accelerate human-centered computing for smart health management. However, limited work has been done to develop advanced IoT technologies for smart monitoring and control of heart health. In this project, we developed a new IoT technology specific to the heart, namely Mobile and E-network Smart Health (MESH) that is an Internet of Hearts (IOH). This IOH technology enables and assists (1) the acquisition of electrocardiogram (ECG) signals pertinent to space-time cardiac dynamics at anytime anywhere; (2) real-time management and compact representation of multi-sensor signals; (3) big data analytics in large-scale IoT contexts.

The MESH technology advances cardiac telemedicine with wireless sensors, smart mobile devices, and big data analytics. This product is developed in the world’s most widely used IOS mobile operating system (i.e., compatible with iPhone, iPad, and iTouch devices). The MESH technology supplies in-situ information processing capabilities, and enables physicians to access the patients’ ECG signals in real time, remotely interact with patients and rapidly respond to life-threatening cardiac disorders.

Our findings in this past year have led to significant research progress, including 1 edited book, 2 book chapters, 2 patents (granted), 4 peer-reviewed conference papers, and 1 journal article (under review), with all products directly related to this award. In addition, our team interviewed cardiovascular patients to understand their “pains” and “needs” (IRB Pro#00018653) as part of this NSF I-Corps project in summer 2014.  We interviewed a total of 31 patients, 33 clinical nurses, 15 cardiologists, 14 medical companies, and 3 insurance companies.

The MESH technology overcomes critical technological barriers in the early identification of acute cardiac events, personalized cardiac monitoring, and smarter management of heart health. The MESH technology will bring the ECG to people's daily life and raise the public awareness of smarter health and wellbeing. Thus, people's individual behavior and habits can be associated with the ECG signals, raising the awareness of smarter health. This positively impacts cardiovascular patients, the largest population at risk of death in the US and in the world.

In addition,this project provided entrepreneurship training to all those participants involved in the project, from the PI, co-PI to undergraduate and graduate students. Thus, the contribution to human resources is significant in that multiple laboratories are working together to train many individuals at all academic levels and cultivate the entrepreneurship spirit in all participants of this project. In addition, the PI, Co-PI and EL's gave NSF I-Corps experience presentation to undergraduate students in courses such as senior capstone design, facility design and cost analysis, as well as to industrial partners in IMSE industry consortium meeting at USF. During the academic year 2014-15, the Co-PI began introduding the ICORPS Lean Start-up materials as a requirement into the sequence of senior design courses in the Bachelors in Industrial Engineering at USF.
